bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John J. Moran, September 11, 1940

div1.p: Hench describes financial arrangements for the Lazear memorial event. He inquires about buildings shown in the Camp Lazear photo.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John J. Moran, September 11, 1940
div1.p:
You will be hearing very shortly from Dr. Hutchison, President
of Washington and Jefferson. He has been trying to get a personal interview
with Mr. Pew. He made a date last week but it had to be cancelled and I understand
he is planning to go to Philadelphia to see him this week. I am sure, confidentially,
that something will be arranged to help take care of your expenses.

I am delighted to hear from General Kean that you are to be
honored by a dinner at the University of Virginia on the twenty-fourth of October.
I wish indeed that I could be there, but I am afraid I will have to meet you in
Washington, Pennsylvania. In Charlottesville, I sincerely hope that you can meet
my brother, Dr. A. L. Hench, who for many years has been Professor of English
Literature at the University of Virginia. I am writing him, telling him of your
coming. Although your time will probably be taken up largely by the medical men,
I hope that you can at least meet my brother and his family.

By separate post, I am sending you a picture of the Lazear
Memorial at Washington and Jefferson.

The most important item is that I hope it isn't too late for me to
call your attention again to Photograph 17, which I sent to you. The more I study
this photograph of Camp Lazear, which shows the various tents and two or three wooden
buildings in the background, the more I wonder whether these wooden buildings and
the white buildings behind them might not be buildings belonging, not to the camp,
but to the San Jose farm. Remember that the Infected Clothing Building number 1
faced due south. With this as a guide, place the photograph on the map of the San
Jose farm and you will find that the San Jose farm house might be in the background.
Will you particularly ask Senora Rojas when you see her if she can identify these
other buildings and in particular the white building behind them in the right back-
ground? Is it by chance the second floor of the San Jose farm house? I also forgot
to ask her whether the farm house has been changed very much in the last fifty years.
If the other buildings and the white building do, in fact, belong to the farm
it would place Camp Lazear rather nearer to the farm house than our impression was.
I know I have asked you to do many favors for me, and I am very anxious to hear from
this. My only defense is, as I told you, that you got me into this, and that it
is a thing which is dear to your heart.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
